description: From Middle English clambren, clameren, clemeren (“to climb, clamber; to crawl, creep”), then either:

The English word is cognate with Low German klemmern, klempern (“to climb”), Scots clammer (“to clamber”); and compare also Danish klamre (“to cling”), Icelandic klambra, klembra (“to pinch closely together; clamp”), Swedish klamra (“to cling”).
The noun is derived from the verb.

entries.meaning: The act of clambering; a difficult or haphazard climb.

verbs.description: clamber (third-person singular simple present clambers, present participle clambering, simple past and past participle clambered)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To climb (something) with some difficulty, or in a haphazard fashion.
examples: The children clambered over the jungle gym.
